This is regarding an open issue https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues/267 which talks about adding theme support to Zulip. Sadly, as discussed, its a huge task to convert CSS to Less first, and then think of any theming.

I have a simpler solution in mind as far as night themes go.

Step 1: Invert the colors of the complete content inside the body tag using CSS filter: invert(100%);.
Step 2: Invert all images, emojis and video elements again, bringing them back to normal.
Step 3: Apply an overlay with translucent background, slightly black and slightly red, to decrease the stress on the eyes.

Just to show what a simple inversion would look like, here is the example.

pasted image
@Tim Abbott @Steve Howell What do you think of this?

That's kind of cool, although obviously it would need a little more work! I wouldn't be discouraged about the comments on the ticket that say we need something like Less to make this work. Most of our CSS complexity deals with fidgety positioning. We could split out the color stuff pretty safely and easily with a few custom tools. And then for areas where fancy inversion tricks don't work, we can just use native CSS:

.night .message {
   font-color: white;
   background: black;
}

.day .message {
    font-color: black;
    background: white;
}

I should make it clear that I do think this is a substantial project to do it right, but I think there are many ways to solve it, and I wouldn't be too discouraged by our current CSS state. We've cleaned up our CSS in many ways lately:

  • we've had tools make the formatting nicer (which makes it easier for subsequent tools to work, too, so a virtuous cycle)
  • we've had people split out some smaller CSS files
  • we just have more CSS expertise on the project
This was just a starting idea. Since that Issue was lying dormant I thought its been forgotten about. The native CSS idea sounds more elegant.

One thing we'll need to guess about here is what the target audience is. Maybe some people need themes for serious reasons (like issues with their eyes), but it could be that most people who want themes just think it's cool to have a customizable app. Our approach may differ based on our assumptions here. If it's more the latter--people want to play around with the app--then we might do more JS kind of stuff, where folks can control stuff from the console.

You don't need to look at these problems as 'theming' really (since that suggests completely new version of the CSS).
For accessibilty you can just append a css file to the already existing bunch of rules. Just as Atom editor does for example to customize the environment.
My personal reason was that at night, almost all my apps are in night mode so whenever I switch to Zulip, it feels like a sudden flash of light.

There are 513 instances of color in our stylesheets according togit grep color static/styles | cat | wc -l. Manually going through the output shows that effectively many of them are setting the same colors.
So here was my idea: Create a new file with all these 513 rules duplicated in them, and then replace all occurrences of one color with another using JS, effectively creating themes.

One thing to note is that there are a few other places we specify color:

border-bottom: 1px solid #fff;

One warmup task would be to go beyond the initial grep investigation and write a tool that sweeps all of our CSS for colors and finds how many distinct colors we have, and how many places each color is specified, both in terms of instances in the CSS code, and and in terms of how many selectors.
Aah. yes. That sounds better. I'll try to compile this list soon.
You may want to look at tools/lib/css_parser.py. It has a parse method that produces a tree-like structure of our CSS data that you can walk to produce this report.

Hey. I tried to use css_parser.py's parse method, but to no success so far. Unfortunately I'll have to take a break from coding for a week because of mid semester exams. I'll get back to this after 4th of April.

I wasn't able to get your method working, so I just wrote this script that identifies colors in the style-sheets:

import tinycss
from tinycss.color3 import parse_color
def parse_file(filename):
    file = open(filename,"r")
    theme = ''
    stylesheet = tinycss.make_parser().parse_stylesheet(file.read())
    for rule in stylesheet.rules:
        for declaration in rule.declarations:
            for value in declaration.value:
                color = parse_color(value)
                if color is not None:
                    print("Found Color:",color)
                    print("Selector(s):")
                    print(rule.selector.as_css())

def main():
    parse_file("sample.css")

main()

I've switched to using the webapp in night mode, because we've talked about switching the default to that because it seems to be the trend.

One thing I've noticed: the green unread marker at the left of each message has been pretty easy to miss. I think giving it more contrast would probably be helpful.

Less confident of this next bit, but the background also feels awfully light-colored to me for a dark/night mode. In general that risks making a lot of things low-contrast...

... of which one specific instance I notice is that the dates in date separators, and the timestamps on messages, are pretty fainly contrasted with the background.
The green unread marker is the same color for both the default and night themes, I think, so I'm sure we could do better there.

I think night themes being dark but not black is the designy thing to do; so I'm not sure we want to change the background color materially.

We certainly can play with the colors. It's intentional that the timestamps are lower contrast than the main text (so they're not distracting), but I'm not sure the same reasoning applies to the date bars; we should probably at least have them use the same bolder styling we use for the date in the recipient bar.
@Alexandra Ciobîcă @Cynthia Lin this may be a good thing for one of you to spend a bit of time on.

One problem with making the date bars too bold is that they may become too noisy in low-traffic realms? Though probably just changing the text to be a bit bolder or darker would be fine.

I think the ideal long-term solution is probably to change the date bars so that the text appears on the right hand side (where the other date/time information is), and then make it the same font as the recipient bar text.
Yeah, agreed. I think bolder to match the existing recipient bars would mean we don't need to remember to do something extra later.

I think night themes being dark but not black is the designy thing to do

Sure, but the point is that ours isn't all that dark.
If you look at e.g. Discord, famous for their dark theme, theirs isn't either.

Material Design recommends a dark gray -- #121212, much darker than our blue-gray hsl(212, 28%, 18%) aka #26303D:
https://material.io/design/color/dark-theme.html#properties

I don't immediately see a specific color mentioned in Apple's HIG:
https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/macos/visual-design/dark-mode/
but it'd be interesting to pin down what they use/prefer too.
But I think ultimately what's important is just that we have sufficient contrast, and it's very achievable with this color.

Login, it's totally different.

Huh indeed -- and I'll agree that that also looks awfully light to me!

OTOH it's basically gray -- saturation 7, vs. our 28. The hue is barely discernible by eye.
Note that the #121212 dark gray in the Material guidelines is the background “surface color”, and text tends to go in overlay boxes that are somewhat lighter.
White vs. our #26303D is a contrast ratio of 13.35 : 1, which fails the Material guidelines for a surface color, but only because a Material app might have text on a 16% white box overlayed on that.
OTOH, the #7F8695 of the date bar vs. #26303D is 3.65 : 1, which is indeed problematic.
And the #0088CC link color vs. #26303D is 3.42 : 1, also problematic.
Huh, the link color certainly doesn't look problematic, visually.
I’d be wary of trusting your eyes over WCAG standards.
